Now in its third edition, this international bestseller has been fully updated to Python 3 and includes a new chapter about how the internet works. What You Will Learn Install Python and get set up for programming Math and data for programming Building GUIs for your programs Creating simple games Adding comments to your code Graphics, sprites, and collision detection Simulate pets and a lunar landing Where to go next on your programming journey This Book Is Written For Like the previous two editions, Hello World! Third Edition is not just for kids. While the tone is light and engaging, it doesn't "talk down" to the reader, and beginners of any age will love its readability and sense of humor. Written by Warren Sande and his son, Carter, it is full of examples that will get you thinking and learning. Reviewed by professional educators, this book is kid-tested and parent-approved. You don't need to know anything about programming to use the book, just the basics of using a computer. If you can start a program and save a file, you can learn to program using this book!

column1: Corporate Finance
column4: "Corporate Finance" by Ivo Welch is a comprehensive textbook that covers the fundamental principles and modern theories of corporate finance. First published in 2009 and now in its fifth edition (as of 2023), the book is widely used in undergraduate and graduate finance courses. Welch, a professor of finance at UCLA Anderson School of Management, takes a practical approach to teaching corporate finance, focusing on real-world applications and decision-making. The book covers topics such as capital budgeting, risk and return, cost of capital, capital structure, dividend policy, and mergers and acquisitions. It also includes sections on financial modeling and valuation techniques. One unique aspect of Welchs book is its emphasis on the use of spreadsheets for financial analysis, with many examples and exercises using Excel. The book is known for its clear explanations, comprehensive coverage, and integration of recent research findings. Welch also provides a free online version of the book, making it accessible to a wider audience

column1: The Accounting Game: Learn the Basics of Financial Accounting - As Easy as Running a Lemonade Stand
column4: A clear, easy-to-understand explanation of key financial accounting basics. The world of accounting can be intimidating. Whether you're a manager, business owner, aspiring entrepreneur, or taking a college course in accounting, you'll find yourself need to know the basics...but baffled by complicated accounting books. What if learning accounting could be as simple and fun as running a child's lemonade stand? It can. The Accounting Game presents financial information in a format so simple and so unlike a common accounting textbook, you may forget you're learning skills that will help you get ahead! Using the world of a child's lemonade stand to teach the basics of managing your finances, this book makes a dry subject fun and understandable. As you run your stand, you'll begin to understand and apply financial terms and concepts like assets, liabilities, earnings, inventory and notes payable, plus: Interactive format gives you hands-on experience Color-coded charts and worksheets help you remember key terms Step-by-step process takes you from novice to expert with ease Fun story format speeds retention of essential concepts Designed to apply what you learn to the real world The revolutionary approach of The Accounting Game takes the difficult subjects of accounting and business finance and makes them something you can easily learn, understand, remember and use! Praise for The Accounting Game: "The game approach makes the subject matter most understandable. I highly recommend it to anyone frightened by either numbers or accountants." —John Hernandis, Director of Corporate Communications, American Greetings "Fantastic Learning Tool...Don't let this book title fool you. It is not an oversimplification of accounting and financial principles. It is, however, a serious and very effective examination of a very small but progressively complex business. There are not many books available on the market that make a complex and dry subject understandable and even fun. This book successfully does just that." —Amazon Reviewer

column1: Financial Statements
column4: "Financial Statements" by Thomas Ittelson is a practical guide to understanding and creating financial reports, aimed at non-financial managers and entrepreneurs. The book explains the three main financial statements (balance sheet, income statement, and cash flow statement) in clear, simple language. Ittelson uses a visual approach and straightforward examples to illustrate how financial transactions affect each statement. The book also covers topics like ratio analysis and basic accounting principles. Its praised for making complex financial concepts accessible to readers without an accounting background

column1: Developing Quality Technical Information: A Handbook for Writers and Editors
column2: Michelle Carey, Moira Lanyi, Deirdre Longo
column4: Drawing on IBM's unsurpassed technical communications experience, readers discover today's best practices for meeting nine quality characteristics: accuracy, clarity, completeness, concreteness, organization, retrievability, style, task orientation, and visual effectiveness. Packed with guidelines, checklists, and before-and-after examples, Developing Quality Technical Information, Third Edition is an indispensable resource for the future of technical communication.

column1: Enterprise Integration Patterns: Designing, Building, Deploying Messaging Solutions
column4: Enterprise Integration Patterns provides an invaluable catalog of sixty-five patterns, with real-world solutions that demonstrate the formidable of messaging and help you to design effective messaging solutions for your enterprise. The authors also include examples covering a variety of different integration technologies, such as JMS, MSMQ, TIBCO ActiveEnterprise, Microsoft BizTalk, SOAP, and XSL. A case study describing a bond trading system illustrates the patterns in practice, and the book offers a look at emerging standards, as well as insights into what the future of enterprise integration might hold. This book provides a consistent vocabulary and visual notation framework to describe large-scale integration solutions across many technologies. It also explores in detail the advantages and limitations of asynchronous messaging architectures. The authors present practical advice on designing code that connects an application to a messaging system, and provide extensive information to help you determine when to send a message, how to route it to the proper destination, and how to monitor the health of a messaging system. If you want to know how to manage, monitor, and maintain a messaging system once it is in use, get this book.

column1: How to Say It
column4: "How to Say It" by Rosalie Maggio is a comprehensive guide to effective written communication, now in its third edition. The book provides templates, phrases, and advice for various types of correspondence, from business letters to personal notes. It covers a wide range of situations, including apologies, complaints, thank-you notes, and condolences. Maggio emphasizes the importance of choosing the right words to convey your message clearly and appropriately. The latest edition includes guidance on email and digital communication. The book is designed as a practical reference for anyone looking to improve their written communication skills.

column1: Business Writing
column4: "Business Writing" by Wilma Davidson is a practical guide to effective written communication in the workplace. First published in 1994 and updated in subsequent editions, the book provides strategies for clear, concise, and persuasive writing in various business contexts. Davidson, an experienced business writing consultant and educator, covers topics such as email etiquette, report writing, proposal development, and crafting effective presentations. The book emphasizes the importance of audience analysis, organization, and revision in producing high-quality business documents. It includes numerous examples, exercises, and checklists to help readers improve their writing skills. Davidson also addresses common grammar and style issues that often plague business writers. The book is designed to be accessible to both novice and experienced writers, making it a valuable resource for professionals at all levels who want to enhance their written communication skills

column1: Business Writing and Communication
column4: "Business Writing and Communication" by Kenneth W. Davis is part of the McGraw-Hill 36-Hour Course series. The book provides a comprehensive overview of business writing and communication skills, designed to be completed in a short timeframe. It covers topics such as writing clear and persuasive business documents, effective email communication, and presentation skills. The book includes practical exercises and self-tests to help readers apply the concepts. Its aimed at professionals looking to quickly improve their business communication skills

column1: The Manager's Path: A Guide for Tech Leaders Navigating Growth and Change
column4: Managing people is difficult wherever you work. But in the tech industry, where management is also a technical discipline, the learning curve can be brutal—especially when there are few tools, texts, and frameworks to help you. In this practical guide, author Camille Fournier (tech lead turned CTO) takes you through each stage in the journey from engineer to technical manager. From mentoring interns to working with senior staff, you’ll get actionable advice for approaching various obstacles in your path. This book is ideal whether you’re a new manager, a mentor, or a more experienced leader looking for fresh advice. Pick up this book and learn how to become a better manager and leader in your organization. Begin by exploring what you expect from a manager Understand what it takes to be a good mentor, and a good tech lead Learn how to manage individual members while remaining focused on the entire team Understand how to manage yourself and avoid common pitfalls that challenge many leaders Manage multiple teams and learn how to manage managers Learn how to build and bootstrap a unifying culture in teams

column1: "The Talk" (about money)
column4: "The Talk" (about money) by Dale Alexander is a guide for young adults on making smart financial decisions early in life. The book focuses on a simple principle of allocating income: living on 70% of your paycheck, investing 20%, and giving away 10%. Alexander argues that adopting this approach from one's first paycheck can lead to significant wealth accumulation over time. He emphasizes the importance of starting this habit early, as it becomes much harder to adjust spending habits later.

column1: Doing Grammar
column4: Doing Grammar is a practical and lively guide to discovering how the English language works. Using strong visuals and an engaging style, Max Morenberg builds upon traditional frameworks with modern linguistic theories and provides accessible explanations for the composition of sentences. Now in its fifth edition, Doing Grammar includes up-to-date examples and features, while retaining its unique voice.

column1: On Writing Well
column4: On Writing Well, which grew out of a course that William Zinsser taught at Yale, has been praised for its sound advice, its clarity, and for the warmth of its style. It is a book for anybody who wants to learn how to write or who needs to do some writing to get through the day, as almost everybody does. Whether you want to write about people or places, science and technology, business, sports, the arts, or about yourself in the increasingly popular memoir genre, On Writing Well offers you both fundamental principles as well as the insights of a distinguished practitioner. How to Write a Memoir tells you how to write the story of your life. Everyone has a story - whether you're a professional writer or just want to validate your personal and family reminiscences, William Zinsser explains how to do it, and do it well.

column1: Writing To Learn
column4: "Writing To Learn" by William Zinsser explores the connection between writing and learning across various disciplines. Published in 1988, the book argues that writing is not just a way to communicate ideas, but also a powerful tool for thinking and learning. Zinsser provides examples from fields like science, mathematics, music, and art to show how writing can deepen understanding and clarify thought. He emphasizes the importance of clear, concise writing in all subjects. The book is aimed at both students and educators, encouraging the use of writing as a learning tool across the curriculum

column1: Six Easy Pieces: Essentials of Physics Explained by Its Most Brilliant Teacher
column2: Richard P. Feynman, Robert B. Leighton, Matthew Sands
column4: Learn how to think like a physicist from a Nobel laureate and "one of the greatest minds of the twentieth century" (New York Review of Books) with these six classic and beloved lessons It was Richard Feynman's outrageous and scintillating method of teaching that earned him legendary status among students and professors of physics. From 1961 to 1963, Feynman delivered a series of lectures at the California Institute of Technology that revolutionized the teaching of physics around the world. Six Easy Pieces, taken from these famous Lectures on Physics, represent the most accessible material from the series. In these classic lessons, Feynman introduces the general reader to the following topics: atoms, basic physics, energy, gravitation, quantum mechanics, and the relationship of physics to other topics. With his dazzling and inimitable wit, Feynman presents each discussion with a minimum of jargon. Filled with wonderful examples and clever illustrations, Six Easy Pieces is the ideal introduction to the fundamentals of physics by one of the most admired and accessible physicists of modern times. "If one book was all that could be passed on to the next generation of scientists it would undoubtedly have to be Six Easy Pieces."- John Gribbin, New Scientist

column1: The Elements of Style
column2: William Strunk Jr., E. B. White
column4: "So friendly, so classic, so delightful . . . Kalman has taken 'the little book' and made it even more elegant and uplifting." —Los Angeles Times The only style manual to ever appear on a bestseller list now refreshed by one of our most beloved illustrators Every English writer knows Strunk and White's The Elements of Style. The book’s mantra, make every word tell, is still on point. This much-loved classic, now in its fourth edition, will forever be the go-to guide when in need of a hint to make a turn of phrase clearer or a reminder on how to enliven prose with the active voice. The only style manual to ever appear on bestseller lists has explained to millions of readers the basic principals of plain English, and Maira Kalman’s fifty-seven exquisite illustrations give the revered work a jolt of new energy, making the learning experience more colorful and clear.

column1: Emotional Intelligence 2.0
column4: "Emotional Intelligence 2.0" by Travis Bradberry and Jean Greaves is a popular book on developing emotional intelligence (EQ) skills. Published in 2009, the book presents a step-by-step program for increasing your EQ through four core skills: self-awareness, self-management, social awareness, and relationship management. The authors, co-founders of TalentSmart, a provider of emotional intelligence tests and training, argue that EQ is a more important factor in success than IQ or technical skills. The book includes access to an online assessment that readers can use to measure their current EQ. It then provides strategies and techniques for improving each of the four EQ skills, with practical tips and exercises. The authors use real-life examples and case studies to illustrate how EQ can be applied in various personal and professional situations. While some critics argue that the concept of EQ is oversimplified, many readers have found the books actionable advice helpful in improving their interpersonal skills and emotional self-regulation

column1: Java Generics and Collections
column4: "Java Generics and Collections" by Maurice Naftalin and Philip Wadler is a comprehensive guide to two important features of the Java programming language: generics and the collections framework. Published in 2006, the book provides an in-depth exploration of how these features work and how they can be used effectively in Java programming. The first part of the book focuses on generics, explaining concepts such as type parameters, wildcards, and type inference. It covers both basic and advanced uses of generics, including their application in class and method design. The second part delves into the Java collections framework, discussing the various interfaces and implementations available, and how generics enhance their use. The authors, both experienced Java programmers and educators, provide numerous code examples and exercises to illustrate key concepts. The book is known for its clear explanations and practical approach, making it valuable for both Java beginners looking to deepen their understanding and experienced programmers seeking to master these important language features

column1: Perl Cookbook
column4: "Perl Cookbook" by Tom Christiansen and Nathan Torkington is a comprehensive resource for Perl programmers, offering solutions to common programming tasks. First published in 1998 and updated in subsequent editions, the book contains hundreds of "recipes" - code snippets and explanations for solving specific problems in Perl. The cookbook covers a wide range of topics, including strings, numbers, dates and times, arrays, hashes, pattern matching, file I/O, databases, user interfaces, web programming, and system administration tasks. Each recipe typically includes a problem statement, a solution, and a discussion explaining how the solution works and exploring alternative approaches. The authors, both experienced Perl programmers and contributors to the Perl community, provide insights into Perl best practices and idiomatic ways of solving problems. While the book is not intended as a tutorial for beginners, it serves as an invaluable reference for both intermediate and advanced Perl programmers, helping them write more efficient and effective code

column1: The Go Programming Language
column4: "The Go Programming Language" by Alan A. A. Donovan and Brian W. Kernighan is the definitive guide to Googles Go programming language. Published in 2015, the book provides a comprehensive introduction to Go, covering its syntax, idioms, and features. Donovan, a staff engineer at Google, and Kernighan, a computer science professor at Princeton University and co-author of the seminal book "The C Programming Language," bring their extensive experience to bear in explaining Gos design philosophy and practical applications. The book starts with basic concepts and gradually introduces more advanced topics, including concurrency, object-oriented programming, and reflection. It includes numerous examples and exercises that demonstrate Gos strengths in areas such as network programming, system programming, and web development. The authors also discuss Go standard library and tools, and provide guidance on writing clear, idiomatic Go code. This book is widely regarded as essential reading for anyone learning Go, from beginners to experienced programmers transitioning from other languages

column1: Proofs: A Long-Form Mathematics Textbook
column4: "Proofs: A Long-Form Mathematics Textbook" by Jay Cummings is an innovative approach to teaching mathematical proofs. Published in 2019, the book is designed to bridge the gap between computational mathematics and proof-based mathematics, which many students find challenging. Cummings, a mathematics educator, takes a more conversational and explanatory approach than traditional textbooks. The book covers fundamental proof techniques including direct proofs, proof by contradiction, proof by induction, and proof by contrapositive. It also explores set theory, logic, functions, and relations. What sets this book apart is its "long-form" approach: rather than presenting terse proofs, it provides detailed explanations of the thought processes behind constructing proofs. Each chapter includes numerous examples, exercises, and "pro tips" that offer insights into mathematical thinking. The book also features introductions to various areas of advanced mathematics at the end of each chapter, giving students a glimpse of where these proof techniques can lead. This approach has made the book popular among self-studiers and students preparing for upper-level mathematics courses

column1: An Introduction to Database Systems
column4: "An Introduction to Database Systems" by C. J. Date is a classic textbook in the field of database management systems. First published in 1975 and now in its eighth edition (as of 2003), the book provides a comprehensive overview of database concepts, design, and implementation. Date, a renowned database expert, covers relational database theory, SQL, transaction management, concurrency control, recovery techniques, and database design. The book is known for its rigorous treatment of relational theory and its emphasis on the importance of a solid theoretical foundation for practical database work. It also discusses object-oriented databases, distributed databases, and data warehousing. Dates writing style is clear and precise, making complex concepts accessible to students and practitioners alike. While some of the specific technologies discussed in earlier editions may be outdated, the fundamental principles and theories presented in the book remain relevant and valuable for anyone seeking a deep understanding of database systems

column1: Ignorance is No Defense: A Teenager's Guide to Georgia Law
column4: "Smart Brevity: The Power of Saying More with Less" by Jim VandeHei, Mike Allen, and Roy Schwartz is a guide to concise and effective communication in the digital age. Published in 2022, the book introduces the concept of "Smart Brevity," a communication strategy developed by the authors for their media company Axios. The authors argue that in a world of information overload, the ability to convey ideas quickly and clearly is crucial. The book provides practical techniques for writing and speaking more efficiently, including how to craft attention-grabbing headlines, structure information for easy consumption, and eliminate unnecessary words and ideas. It covers applications of Smart Brevity in various contexts, including emails, presentations, and meetings. The authors draw on their experience in journalism and business to provide real-world examples and case studies. While some critics argue that the approach may oversimplify complex issues, many readers have found the books strategies helpful in improving their communication skills and capturing audience attention in a fast-paced information environment

column2: Jim VandeHei, Mike Allen, Roy Schwartz
column4: "Introductory Discrete Mathematics" by V.K. Balakrishnan is a concise textbook aimed at undergraduate students in computer science and mathematics. Published in 1991, it emphasizes combinatorics, graph theory, and algorithms for network optimization problems. The book covers fundamental topics like set theory, logic, counting principles, generating functions, and recurrence relations. It also includes chapters on more advanced subjects like graph theory and network optimization algorithms. The text is known for its clear explanations and numerous examples, making it accessible to beginners while still providing a solid foundation in discrete mathematics
